TopicTitle: Kerbal crashes and restarts my mid-2012 Macbook Pro Retina

Articles.Content:
Hi, I can no longer launch KSP on my mid-2012 Macbook Pro Retina. Just last week it was working fine. I'd appreciate some help.

  • I'm running the copy of Kerbal I bought off Steam, it's the latest version (0.90), and my OS is 10.10.1
  • Essentially, every time I launch the game, it quickly (a minute or less) crashes not just the game, but my entire system. The laptop instantly reboots, and may crash several more times upon trying to start itself up. In order to get it all the way to my desktop, I have to try a few times and hold down Shift during startup to stop any Saved States from loading. When it restarts for the first time, a screen similar to this one appears, but it reads slightly differently, along the lines of: "Your computer has had to restart..."
  • I don't get far enough to include a screenshot of anything.
  • I've taken a look at the Player.log file in console - it's empty, nothing to share there other than that. Upon a few searches, I did find some logs from the KSP launcher, which look like this:

  • My system specs can be found here (left side column).

I've tried deleting the saved state in Saved Application States, and that hasn't helped. I've also reinstalled the game twice.

Haven't found anything about this issue online, and I was just starting to really get into the game. Any ideas?

Thanks for your help.

Your laptop is crashing before KSP even starts. That indicates a serious problem with the laptop, not KSP. The issue in this screenshot is not likely to cause significant problems Ã¢â‚¬â€œ it just means that the KSP Launcher is reading the OS X version in an old way.

You can check the hard disk using Disk Utility and test your RAM, but this may also result from hardware failure elsewhere in the system, especially the graphics card.

Hmm, ok. I've verified/repaired the hard drive using the recovery tools accessible when you boot and hold command+R. That doesn't seem to be the issue. Maybe testing the RAM will help.

In any case, I've made appointment with an Apple Service provider to address some other issues, I'll make sure to ask about this as well.

Thanks for your help.

This was indeed found to be a Mac kernel panic issue, exposed (but not caused) by Kerbal. $310 and 5 days from now I will be back on my way to the Mun...

Cheers, and thanks again for the help Master Tao.
